Nepali professionals living in Berlin gathered for a summit to discuss issues that affect them, such as career, education, and social integration.

The summit provided a platform for networking, sharing experiences, and exchanging ideas.
content: The Second Nepali Professionals' Summit in Germany brought together 70 Nepali professionals to share knowledge and skills. title: Rato Machhindranath Jatra, a popular chariot festival in Kathmandu, Nepal, has begun. The festival celebrates the God Machhindranath and involves pulling his chariot through the streets. The chariot is believed to bring good luck and prosperity to the city.
content: The Rato Machhindra jatra started today, with a chariot procession for the god of rain and good times. The chariot was built at Pulchowk and is now being taken to Gahbahal with music. After going through all the streets of Patan, the chariot will reach Jawalakhel, where the famous bhoto jatra will take place.
summary: Rato Machindranath's chariot, a symbol of rain and prosperity, embarked on a journey from Pulchowk to Gahbahal, showcasing the renowned bhoto jatra.

title: Sarlahi section witnesses 90% progress in East-West Electric Railway.
content: 90% of the East-West Electric Railway in Sarlahi district is done. The 30-km track is almost open, but there are some delays due to trees not being cleared. The construction company is working faster now. However, the company hasn't been paid for the work they've already done.
summary: East-West Electric Railway construction in Sarlahi district is 90% complete, with ongoing track opening and infrastructure setup, but progress has slowed due to payment delays and forest clearing issues.

title: Political instability hurts development, says Chairperson Oli.
content:
Nepal's political leader admits that instability has hurt the country's progress. He says infrastructure, such as roads and railways, is important for development, especially for small businesses in agriculture. He promises to support these businesses and build more infrastructure.

Other leaders also spoke about the need to improve spending on infrastructure and for all political parties to work together on development. The deputy prime minister pledged to make progress in the physical infrastructure sector.

Experts will present their ideas on improving roads, railways, and other infrastructure at the seminar.
summary: CPN (UML) Chair Oli acknowledges political instability's impact on development and highlights the significance of physical infrastructure development, emphasizing SMEs and upcoming fiscal year programs.

title: The Swiss government will give 9.01 million Swiss francs to a tourism project.
content:
Switzerland will provide 9 million Swiss francs to Nepal for a 4-year trekking tourism project. The project aims to help 100,000 locals in 29 areas of Koshi Province by:

- Preserving local culture and art
- Boosting local businesses
- Creating jobs
- Promoting eco-friendly tourism

The project is expected to strengthen the tourism industry in Koshi Province and improve the economy for locals.
summary: Switzerland grants Nepal 9.01 million Swiss francs for a four-year trekking-based tourism project in Koshi Province, benefiting 100,000 locals and promoting sustainable tourism.

title: Four people have been arrested for leaking Grade 12 exam papers.
content: Police arrested four people in Kathmandu for cheating in the Grade-12 computer science exam using leaked question papers. The arrested individuals were caught writing answers for the exam, which was scheduled to be held between 8:00am and 10:00am on Wednesday. Investigation is ongoing under the Education Act 2028.
summary: Kathmandu police arrest four individuals with leaked Grade-12 answer sheets, leading to an investigation under the Education Act.

title: 105 crocodiles released into Rapti River.
content: 105 Gharial crocodiles were released into the Rapti river to protect them. They were raised at a breeding center with the aim of increasing their survival rates. The breeding center has released 1,957 crocodiles into different rivers since 2035 BS. There are currently 622 crocodiles in the breeding center. Gharial crocodiles are critically endangered and face challenges from human activities and border crossings.
summary: Chitwan National Park's Gharial Crocodile Breeding Center has released 105 Gharial crocodiles into the Rapti River, raising the total number released in Nepal's rivers to 1,957 despite challenges such as border crossings and human activities.

title: Joshi Dhakal has been promoted to the rank of Assistant Inspector General (AIG) in Nepal Police. This decision was made by the Cabinet led by Prime Minister Pushpa Kamal Dahal 'Prachanda'.
content:
The government has promoted Deputy Inspectors General Umesh Raj Joshi and Bhim Prasad Dhakal to Additional Inspectors General of Nepal Police.

The government also awarded 42 athletes, coaches, and managers who won medals in international sports competitions, including taekwondo, kabaddi, karate, and cricket.

Nanda Lal Majhi has been appointed as Vice Chairman of the Social Welfare Council and Suresh Manandhar has been appointed as Member of the Language Commission.

title: Construction of a new bridge along the Narayangadh-Muglin road section is in full progress, aiming to enhance transportation and safety in the area.
content:
11 of 15 bridges on the Narayangadh-Muglin road are open.
4 bridges are under construction: Khahare, Namche, Kalikhola, and Tuin Khola.
2 bridges, Khahare and Namche, will open by mid-July.
Tuin Khola bridge will open by mid-November.
Construction delays are due to cutting a wall near Tuin rivulet and paying compensation in Khahare.
Improved roads and bridges reduce rainy season problems.
summary: Construction of 11 out of 15 bridges on the Narayangadh-Muglin road section is complete, with four more under construction and set for completion by mid-November, facilitating smoother transportation.

title: National Assembly meeting postponed due to protests from the National Council of South Africa (NCSA).
content:
**National Assembly Meeting Postponed**

The second assembly meeting was postponed due to protests by opposition party NC.

NC lawmakers demanded an investigation into embezzlement in cooperatives before allowing the meeting to continue.

Despite a brief pause for an NC member to speak, the NC continued their protest, leading to the postponement of the meeting until May 14.
summary: The second National Assembly meeting was postponed due to protests from NC lawmakers demanding a probe into cooperative embezzlement allegations.

title: House adjourned over opposition protests
content: The opposition party (NC) blocked the second meeting of the House of Representatives (HoR) on Friday. They want a committee to investigate missing cooperative funds. When a minister accused of involvement in the scandal tried to speak, the opposition stopped him, and the meeting was adjourned. The next meeting is scheduled for May 14th.
summary: Nepali Congress protests obstruct House of Representatives meetings, preventing debate on cooperative funds investigation.

title: Today, the federal parliament's budget session starts.
content: Today, the federal parliament began its budget session, where the government will present its plans for the upcoming year. The session was summoned by President Ramchandra Paudel after consulting with the Council of Ministers. By May 28th, the government must present its budget, outlining its spending and income plans. The session aims to ensure smooth operations and has been discussed with opposition party leaders.
summary: The budget session of the Nepalese federal parliament commences today, with the presentation of the annual budget on May 28 and the President's policy and program speech before that.

title: Government ignores concerns raised by the Chief Whip of the main opposition party.
content:
The opposition party (Nepali Congress) is demanding an investigation into stolen money from cooperatives. They also want the government to clean up the cooperative sector.

However, they don't want to overthrow the government or work with the UML party.

Instead, they want to work with other parties to address the people's needs. They believe the parliament should be strong and focus on the people's concerns.
summary: Nepal’s Chief Whip Lekhak demands investigation into cooperative misappropriation, cleanups of the sector, and consensus with major parties to prioritize citizens’ needs and address parliament’s effectiveness.

title: Deputy Prime Minister Lamichhane wants to speak in parliament.
content: Deputy Prime Minister Rabi Lamichhane says his right to speak in parliament was taken away. He wants to speak about allegations against him and prove he is innocent. He thinks parliament should not be controlled by other parties. The government is trying to catch the main person involved in a scam involving financial cooperatives.
summary: Deputy Prime Minister Rabi Lamichhane demands the right to speak in parliament amid accusations and a potential probe into cooperative issues, while challenging opponents to provide evidence and affirming efforts to apprehend the main accused in the scam.

title: Minister Joshi urges providing immediate relief to build shelters for earthquake survivors in Jajarkot.
content:
**Minister Joshi Calls for Urgent Shelter Assistance for Earthquake Survivors**

Minister Joshi emphasizes the need for swift aid to help those left homeless by the recent earthquake. He urges immediate compensation and construction of temporary shelters before the rainy season.

Despite ongoing recovery efforts from the 2015 earthquake, the country continues to face frequent disasters. Minister Joshi stresses the importance of implementing disaster risk reduction policies effectively.

He praises the National Reconstruction Authority for its efforts but highlights the need for stronger collaboration between federal, provincial, and local governments in disaster management. Over 100,000 homes need to be rebuilt in Karnali Province alone.
summary: Minister Joshi emphasizes the urgent need for relief and compensation for earthquake victims in Jajarkot and stresses the importance of disaster risk reduction and management in the face of frequent disasters in Nepal.

title: Tragic fire kills mother and son.
content:
A mother and her son died in a community forest fire in Siddhicharan Municipality.

The mother was protecting hay when she caught fire. Her son tried to save her but was also burned.

Police are investigating the incident and other forest fires are ongoing in the district.
summary: A mother and son perished in a forest fire while trying to protect hay, triggering an ongoing investigation into the incident.

title: Two people were killed and two others were injured in a road accident.
content: Two people, including the tractor driver, died in a road accident involving a tractor in Dadeldhura. Two others were injured and are being treated at a hospital.
summary: Two individuals perished in a road mishap involving a tractor in Dadeldhura, resulting in two more injuries.

title: 24 artifacts from Hawaii have been returned to Nepal.
content:
The Embassy in the US received 24 artifacts from Ms. Bradford, a private collector in Hawaii. The artifacts date back to the 13th, 17th, and 18th centuries. Ms. Bradford donated the shipping costs to return them to Nepal.
The Embassy thanked Ms. Bradford for her generous return of the artifacts, which are important to Nepal's heritage. The Embassy has been working to recover lost artifacts and has successfully sent a total of 63 pieces back to Nepal within the past year.
summary: The Embassy of Nepal recovered and repatriated 24 ancient artifacts from the private collection of Ms. Susan Bradford and sent them to the Department of Archaeology in Nepal.

title:
**HWPL Statement on Israel-Iran Conflict**

The Humanitarian Welfare Council (HWPL) condemns the escalating conflict between Israel and Iran.

* Calls for an immediate ceasefire to protect civilians.
* Urges all parties to engage in constructive dialogue and peaceful negotiations.
* Emphasizes the importance of respecting international law and humanitarian principles.
* Calls for global cooperation to resolve the conflict and promote peace in the region.
content:
**Iran and Israel Conflict**

* Iran and Israel are attacking each other, violating international law.
* Innocent civilians are the main victims of war.
* The world is urging Iran and Israel to stop fighting and start peace talks.
* HWPL, a peace organization, calls for international cooperation to facilitate peace and provide humanitarian aid.
* The world should support international agreements for peace to leave a legacy of peace for future generations.
summary:
The recent violent conflict between Iran and Israel is causing significant concerns in the international community. The two nations that do not share borders are mobilizing high-end weaponry to attack each other and kill human lives.1 April 2024, the Israeli military attacked the Iranian consulate in Syria. A strike against a non-military facility in a third nation, a nation not directly involved in the conflict, infringes international law and constitutes a war crime. Moreover, on 13 April, Iran responded by attacking Israel’s land. Both nations have pointed their guns directly at each other, and there are growing concerns in the international community that the attacks could escalate into another war.
The Israel-Hamas War in Gaza has killed 30,000 since last year, and news outlets reported on dire situations in Gaza, running out of space for proper burial. The war that has persisted in the region over the past century continuously overshadows the prospect of the coexistence of the human race.
It is a clear indication that the greatest victims of war are innocent civilians. How could those lost lives ever be brought back? What could compensate for the outcry of children and the anguish of the youth in devastated dwellings?
HWPL strongly supports the voices of the citizens, the true protagonists of the global village, who oppose war and call for peace. All nations of the global community must uphold the citizens’ demands, thereby ceasing the unjust war and joining to accomplish peace. Organizations worldwide, in alliance with HWPL as peace solidarity, urge Iran and Israel to put a stop to the acts of aggression immediately and to come forward for conversations to usher in peace.
HWPL recommend that the international community take necessary measures to facilitate the formation of amicable relations between the two nations and provide humanitarian aid. It would be reasonable for all countries to support an international legal instrument for peace that embodies the long-yearned path to peace and to comply with its contents so that we leave a legacy of peace for future generations. HWPL will not spare its efforts for peace and cessation of wars.

title: Nepal and Korea plan for a high-level exchange visit to strengthen their relationship.
content:
Nepal and South Korea have had diplomatic relations for 50 years.

To celebrate, they are planning events and high-level visits.

South Korea is the 4th largest investor in Nepal and plans to invest more in hydropower.

Nepalis have been going to Korea to work since 2008, with over 44,000 currently working there.

Nepalis are now working in more sectors in Korea, including service and forestry.

Nepalis who return from Korea start businesses in Nepal.
summary: Nepal and the Republic of Korea celebrate 50 years of diplomatic relations, preparing for high-level visits, commemorative programs, and increased investment in hydropower and other sectors.

title: Japan's Foreign Minister Yoko Kamikawa says Japan and Nepal have a lot in common.
content:
**Japan and Nepal: Shared Challenges and Cooperation**

Japan and Nepal share a mountainous landscape and have faced challenges due to earthquakes. Both countries prioritize democracy and have provided mutual assistance in times of need.

Despite limited natural resources, Japan supports Nepal's development in areas such as infrastructure, agriculture, and healthcare. The Nagdhunga tunnel, a major infrastructure project, will boost Nepal's transportation network.

Japan values Nepal's role in UN peacekeeping and sees potential for cooperation on "Women, Peace and Security" initiatives. The two countries will celebrate 70 years of diplomatic relations in 2026, and Japan will continue to support Nepal's future development.
summary: Japan and Nepal, facing similar mountainous terrain, have a long-standing relationship built on mutual assistance in times of natural disasters and support for democracy and economic development, with an emphasis on women's empowerment and infrastructure projects.

title: Government supports and protects investments.
content: Prime Minister Dahal wants to improve Nepal's economy by encouraging investment and supporting businesses. He believes that having a friendly environment for investors, especially those in the industry sector, will attract more investment and create jobs. He mentioned that the government is working to make policies that help businesses grow and create jobs, and that the recent investment summit showed that Nepal is becoming an attractive place for investors.
summary: Prime Minister Pushpa Kamal Dahal pledges to boost economic growth by supporting investors and the private sector, emphasizing the importance of domestic production and job creation through industry-friendly policies.

title: European Union to support Nepal in attracting foreign investment
content: The European Union (EU) is organizing a "EU-Nepal Trade Forum" in Kathmandu to help Nepal attract European investments. The forum will connect European companies with potential investment opportunities in Nepal. The goal is to support Nepal's efforts to grow its economy and reduce foreign investment needs.
summary: The EU will hold an investment forum in Nepal on May 15-16 to promote European investment and support Nepal's economic development goals.

title: Transparency and good governance go hand-in-hand. They are both essential for a well-functioning society. Transparency means that the government is open and honest with its citizens. Good governance means that the government is run efficiently and effectively.
content:
**Summary:**

President Paudel says that transparency and good governance are important. He calls auditors the nation's "economic watchdogs" because they ensure accuracy in financial records.

Auditors help prevent corruption and promote accountability in economic activities. They are essential for improving the credibility of financial systems and promoting economic development.

The conference will discuss Nepal's economic challenges and solutions, with experts from various fields participating in the discussions.
summary: President Paudel emphasizes transparency in governance, commends auditors as economic watchdogs, and ACAN holds national conference on economic crisis and solutions.

title: PM Dahal announces a new approach to presenting the upcoming budget.
content: Prime Minister Prachanda says the government will focus on improving the economy for those who are struggling financially and working towards socialism. He will gather input from various parties to make the upcoming budget more people-friendly. The government has also been working on good governance and justice, such as cracking down on illegal activities and helping loan shark victims. Despite criticism, the government will continue to implement reforms. Nepal's foreign relations have also improved, with increased high-level visits.
summary: Prime Minister Prachanda announces a new policy and budget format, emphasizing economic improvement, inclusion, and good governance, with input requested from diverse parties and a commitment to continue reform efforts.

**Nepal Swadeshi Summit 2024 Declaration**

35 points issued to:

* Promote domestic production
* Reduce foreign dependency
* Strengthen national economy
* Ensure self-reliance
content:
**Make in Nepal Summit: A Plan for Growth**

The summit ended with a list of 35 steps to help:

* Improve local businesses
* Increase production of Nepali goods
* Make Nepali products more popular

The government promised to:

* Support businesses with production
* Use Nepali products in government offices
* Encourage private sector growth

The plan also calls for:

* Changing laws to help businesses
* Making it easier to find raw materials
* Setting up a special bank for industrial investment
* Creating a website to showcase Nepali products
* Using One Stop Service Centres
* Promoting industrial areas

* Encouraging production of competitive goods
* Fining instead of charging industrialists with crimes
* Reviewing trade agreements
* Building agreement among political parties for stability
summary: The 'Make in Nepal-Swadheshi Summit-2024' concluded with a 35-point declaration focused on empowering local industries, increasing domestic production, and encouraging consumption.

title: Economic growth is starting in Dailekh, according to Minister Bhandari.
content: Dailekh district could become economically prosperous if oil exploration in Jaljale is successful. The government inaugurated the final drilling stage and is hopeful it will bring economic prosperity to Nepal. The exploration, funded by China, will determine how much oil and gas is available in Dailekh. Successful exploration could make it an economic hub.
summary: Minister Damodar Bhandari inaugurated the final drilling phase of petroleum exploration in Dailekh, hoping the successful exploration would pave the way for economic prosperity in Nepal.

title: Nepalese runners won two titles in Malaysia.
content:
Nepalese runner Mahadev Rijal won two consecutive titles in Malaysia:

* **Half Marathon (21 km):** Completed in 0:1:14:48, placing first.
* **Climbathon (21 km):** Completed in 3:03:58, placing first overall.

Rijal has also been the 8th Tower Runner in Malaysia, completing a race with 83 flights of stairs in 9:22.
summary: Nepali runner Mahadev Rijal achieved consecutive victories in Malaysia, winning the 21 km half marathon and 21 km Climbathon events with record-breaking times, adding to his previous achievements as the 8th Tower Runner in 2023.

title: Nepal defeated West Indies A in the final match of the T20 series.
content:
Nepal won the final T20 match against West Indies 'A' by six wickets, after losing the first three matches.

West Indies scored 172 runs first.

Nepal chased the target and won in 18.5 overs, thanks to Anil Shah's 58 runs and Kushal Malla's 37 runs.
summary: Nepal triumphed in the T20 series finale against West Indies 'A' by six wickets, despite earlier setbacks in the series.

title: President sends good wishes to cricket players.
content: President Ramchandra Paudel wished the Nepali cricket team good luck in the ICC T20 World Cup, which starts on June 1st. The team is leaving for the US tonight. Nepal is in Group D with South Africa, Sri Lanka, Bangladesh, and the Netherlands. Their first match is against the Netherlands on June 4th.
summary: President Paudel extended best wishes to Nepali cricket team departing for ICC T20 World Cup, which begins June 1st, where they will face the Netherlands in their first match.

title: West Indies A won the T20 series against India A.
content: West Indies 'A' won the T20 series against Nepal before the last match by winning the fourth match by 28 runs. They scored 209 runs batting first, and Nepal was bowled out for 181 runs chasing the target. Andre Fletcher (84 runs) was the top scorer for West Indies 'A', and Rohit Kumar Paudel (82 runs) was the top scorer for Nepal. Hayden Walsh and Matthew Forde took three wickets each for West Indies 'A'. The last match will be played on Saturday.
summary: West Indies 'A' clinched the T20 series title after defeating Nepal by 28 runs in the fourth match, despite the fifth match still pending.

title: Nepal lost its third Twenty20 match by 76 runs to the West Indies.
content: Nepal lost to West Indies 'A' by 76 runs in the T20 series. Nepal failed to chase the 228 run target, scoring only 151 in 19.2 overs. Karan KC (28) and Lokesh Bam (28) were the top scorers for Nepal. West Indies batted first and scored 227 runs, with Johnson Charles scoring 119 and Andre Fletcher scoring 53. Karan KC and Sagar Dhakal took 1 wicket each for Nepal. Nepal has won 2 and lost 1 match in the 5-match series.
summary: Nepal lost to West Indies 'A' in the third T20 match by 76 runs, despite Karan KC's 28 and Johnson Charles' century for the visitors.

title: Nepalese team heads to Asian U20 Athletics Championship
content:
Nepalese team heads to Dubai for Asian U-20 Athletics Championships:
- Badal Karki: 800m and 1500m
- Adeshkumar Yadav: 100m and 200m
- Ajay B.K: 1500m and 3000m
- Kalpana Budha: 1500m and 3000m

summary: The National Sports Council sent a team to the Asian U-20 Athletics Championships, with players competing in various running events and coached by Kanti Mahato.

title: Dengue cases in Bagmati province of Nepal have exceeded 11,000, posing a significant health concern.
content:
Bagmati Province has seen over 11,000 dengue fever cases since July 2023.
Dhading has the most cases (3,501), while Rasuwa has the least (2).
Kathmandu has reported 3,000 cases, Chitwan 1,708, and Makwanpur 857.
One person has died in Makwanpur due to dengue.
The risk of dengue is higher in summer, and the Health Directorate is urging people to take precautions.
A campaign is being planned to find and destroy mosquito larvae to fight dengue.
summary: Bagmati Province has reported over 11,000 confirmed dengue cases in the past nine months, with the highest cases in Dhading and the lowest in Rasuwa.

title: Nepal's approach to population and development places the rights of individuals at the core. This means ensuring access to health, education, and other essential services for all, regardless of their background or circumstances. This approach recognizes that investing in people's well-being is crucial for both social and economic progress.
content: Nepal believes that everyone has the right to health and a good life. Nepal is working to make sure that every citizen has a good quality of life by implementing policies and programs that focus on people's rights. Nepal is committed to achieving the goals set out in the International Conference on Population and Development (ICPD), which include reducing poverty and improving health and education for all.
summary: Nepal affirms a rights-based approach to population and development, emphasizing the importance of ICPD implementation and addressing challenges in achieving SDGs due to pandemics, conflicts, and climate change.

title: Japan donates community center for disaster preparedness.
content:
Japan built a new community center in Sindhupalchowk, Nepal, to help the community prepare for and prevent disasters. The center will include:

* A building
* Disaster prevention committees
* Training and activities
* Public announcements
* Warehouses
* Landslide prevention measures

The center is expected to help improve disaster prevention capabilities and revitalize the region.
summary: Japan provides a Community Center for Disaster Prevention in Sindhupalchowk District to enhance disaster prevention capabilities through construction, committee establishment, broadcasting, warehousing, and landslide prevention measures.

title: Dr. Sharma, a parliamentarian, donated 2 million rupees to a children's hospital.
content: Dr Sunil Sharma, a member of Parliament, gave 2 million rupees to support the construction of a children's hospital in Kathmandu. This hospital is being built by Dr Bhagwan Koirala, a heart surgeon. The plan is to build specialized children's hospitals in all seven provinces of Nepal, including one in Kathmandu.
summary: MP Dr Sharma donates 2 million rupees to Cardiothoracic Surgeon Dr Bhagwan Koirala's initiative to build a children's hospital in Kathmandu.

title: Dr. Sharma, a parliament member, donated 2 million rupees to a children's hospital.
content: MP Dr. Sharma donated 2 million rupees to Children's Hospital being built by Dr. Koirala. The hospital aims to build children's hospitals in all seven provinces of Nepal. One hospital is already operating in Damak, Jhapa. The Kathmandu hospital will have 100 beds, and 50-bed hospitals are planned for other provinces.
summary: Entrepreneur Dr. Sunil Sharma donated two million rupees to the under-construction Kathmandu Institute of Child Health, which aims to build specialized children's hospitals in all seven provinces of Nepal.

title: Children receiving vitamin A capsules and deworming tablets
content:
**Vitamin 'A' and De-worming Program for Children**

The government launched a 2-day program to give Vitamin 'A' capsules to kids 6 months to 59 months old and de-worming tablets to kids 1 to 5 years old.

Around 3.2 million kids will get Vitamin 'A' capsules, and about 2.9 million will get de-worming tablets.

Health volunteers will give out the capsules and tablets in every ward. The government gives these free to kids twice a year.
summary: Nepal's Health Department launches a two-day National Vitamin 'A' program, targeting 3.2 million children for vitamin 'A' capsules and 2.9 million for de-worming tablets.

title: Private companies ask Prime Minister to support daily flights at Gia Lai Airport.
content: Business leaders in Bhairahawa have asked Prime Minister Dahal to start regular flights at the Gautam Buddha International Airport. The Prime Minister responded positively and said efforts were being made.
summary: Bhairahawa's private sector urged PM Dahal to facilitate regular flights at Gautam Buddha International Airport, which he responded positively to.

title: The ropes for climbing Mount Everest have been put in place, making the route to the summit safer for climbers.
content:
Rope fixing for Mount Everest's spring climbing season is complete.

The Seven Summit Treks Company fixed ropes to the peak, allowing climbers to ascend safely.

Over 950 climbers, including 200 women, have obtained permits for 30 mountains, including Everest.

The government has collected over 67 crore rupees from climbers.

With rope fixing done, climbing has opened for those with permits.
summary: Seven Summit Treks Company has completed 'rope fixing' up to Mt. Everest's peak, opening the climbing season for 956 permitted climbers, including 200 women.

title: Today marks the grand finale of the Maha Kumbha Mela, a sacred Hindu festival.
content: The 12-year Pindeshwar Poorna Mahakumbha Mela has ended after running for a month in Barahkshetra Municipality. It is believed that the Saptakoshi river in Barahkshetra is connected to the Kumbha Mela in Hindu scriptures. This has led to people from all over the country and abroad visiting the area for the festival, which has been held for many years.
summary: The 12-year Pindeshwar Poorna Mahakumbha Mela, held in Chatradham, concludes after a month, drawing pilgrims from near and far due to its connection with the Kumbha Melas in India, as stated in Hindu scriptures.

title: Rhino conservation faces challenges: 21 rhinos killed in 10 months.
content:
In the past 10 months, 21 rhinos died in Chitwan National Park area.

Two were killed by hunters, while 19 died from natural causes like getting stuck in swamps or fighting with each other.

The park is working to improve rhino habitats to help protect them.

There are currently 694 rhinos in the park.
summary: In Chitwan National Park, 21 rhinos died in the past year; 2 from poaching and 19 due to natural causes, including habitat issues, with the park implementing conservation measures to manage the growing population.

title: Government to create a special fund to support innovation in the IT sector and encourage growth.
content: Prime Minister Prachanda plans to create an innovation fund in the upcoming budget to support the growth of the information technology industry. The government aims to encourage young scientists to use technology for income and promote the "Startup Programme" for youth. The Prime Minister believes technology is key to economic prosperity and social transformation. Measures will be taken to prevent cybercrime and ensure the safe use of technology.
summary: PM Dahal announces plans for an innovation fund for the ICT sector, emphasizes the role of technology in economic growth, and vows to combat cybercrime.

title: Today, we celebrate National ICT Day to highlight the importance of information and communication technologies in our daily lives.
content:
Today is National ICT Day, a day to celebrate and promote the development and use of technology in Nepal.

The government has planned special events, including an awards ceremony to recognize those who have made significant contributions to the ICT sector.

The government believes that technology is key to Nepal's economic prosperity and plans to use it to drive social and economic transformation.
summary: Nepal celebrates National ICT Day (May 2) to promote ICT development, honoring contributors, and implementing initiatives for technological advancement and socio-economic transformation.

title: Politics can boost investor enthusiasm and attract investments to the president's country.
content:

President Paudel believes that Nepal can become prosperous through energy development. He urges the government to support investors, while the private sector should prioritize Nepal's well-being. Federalism is enhancing political stability, attracting investment. Nepal has transitioned from importing energy to exporting it, boosting the economy and contributing to clean energy use in the region.
summary: President Paudel emphasizes the need for political enthusiasm for investment in Nepal's energy sector, highlighting its potential for prosperity through rapid energy development.

title: A new bill aims to make sure that artificial intelligence (AI) is used in a clear and responsible way. It wants to make sure that AI is used for good and not for harm. The bill calls for transparency and accountability in the use of AI so that people can understand how and why it is being used.
content:
Draft bill on IT and cyber security in Nepal:

- Technology like AI, machine learning, and blockchain will be used in safe and responsible ways.
- A center for research will be established for new technologies.
- A committee will be formed to respond quickly to cyber security issues.
- The bill covers electronic records, data security, digital signatures, and cyber crimes.
- Data safety measures include preventing harm to national unity and security.
- Cyber bullying and data theft are prohibited.
- Government entities must have a website and follow standards set by the Ministry of Communications.
- Domain names and cyber security services require registration and licensing.
summary: The draft IT and cyber security bill incorporates AI, machine learning, blockchain, and IoT while establishing structures for research, coordination, and enforcement of cyber security measures.

title: Minister Sharma highlights the urgency for comprehensive cyber legislation to address various problems and challenges faced in the digital realm.
content: Cybersecurity is important and a new law is needed to address problems. The government is working on a new law, but needs feedback. Public awareness is also important to ensure cybersecurity.
summary: Communications Minister Rekha Sharma highlights the need for cyber legislation and public awareness due to increasing challenges and misuse of information technology.

summary: Officials from Nepal and Bangladesh agreed to a power trade deal, with Nepal exporting electricity to Bangladesh during the rainy season.

title:
**Yakishime: Earth Metamorphosis Exhibition**

This exhibition showcases the ancient Japanese ceramic technique of Yakishime. Through a variety of works, it explores how this technique can create beautiful and unique forms from the earth.
content: Japan is holding an exhibition from May 11th to 30th at the Embassy Hall in Kathmandu. The exhibition will showcase yakishime, a type of traditional Japanese pottery that is unglazed and high-fired. Yakishime is used for serving food and drink, and it has a unique sensibility and aesthetic that is unfamiliar to many people outside of Japan. The exhibition will provide visitors with an opportunity to experience the depth and diversity of Japanese culture.
summary: An exhibition showcases the evolution and cultural significance of Japanese yakishime ceramics, offering insights into Japanese tradition and aesthetics.

title: Victims and activists say reparations are not enough. They demand truth and prosecution for those who committed violent crimes during conflicts.
content:
**Reparations for Conflict Victims**

The government is preparing a plan to provide support to victims of the conflict era. This support, called reparations, is important for victims who have been waiting for justice for years.

However, reparations are not meant to replace other steps needed for peace, such as finding out the truth about what happened and punishing those responsible.

Stakeholders say all levels of government should work together to provide reparations fairly and equitably. The plan should include:

* Restoring victims' property or providing a substitute
* Helping victims recover from physical and mental injuries
* Compensating victims financially
* Offering official apologies and creating memorials to honor victims

The plan should also consider the needs of victims who have been sexually abused or tortured. To make the plan effective, victims should be involved in its development, and their needs should be taken into account.
summary: Eighteen years after the Comprehensive Peace Accord, Nepal prepares its reparation action plan facing caution from human rights defenders against presenting reparations as a substitute for other transitional justice elements.

title: Makeup consumers are worried because low-cost knockoffs of expensive makeup brands are flooding the market.
content:
**Cosmetic Safety Concerns in Nepal**

**Lead Contamination:**

* Lipsticks and other cosmetics contain high levels of lead, which can cause health problems.
* Lead is used to make products last longer and adhere better, but it is harmful and should not be in cosmetics.

**Counterfeit Products:**

* Fake cosmetics often contain harsh chemicals and are not made to standards.
* Counterfeits can cause skin irritation, dryness, or even more serious health issues.

**Lack of Regulation:**

* Nepal does not have a government agency that regulates chemicals in cosmetics.
* This means consumers are not protected from unsafe products.

**What Consumers Can Do:**

* Buy cosmetics from authorized retailers.
* Read product labels carefully.
* Look for variations in packaging and inspect the product's texture.
* Be aware of the risks of counterfeit products.
* Support government efforts to regulate cosmetics and protect consumers.
summary: Concerns grow over the safety of cosmetics in Nepal due to rampant lead contamination and unregulated chemical usage, leading to severe health issues and the need for strict regulatory measures.

* The ICP promotes trade between Nepal and India.

* The one-window system makes it easier for traders.
* The facility reduces queues of cargo trucks at the border.

* Customs clearance time has now reduced to a few hours.
summary: Integrated Check Post (ICP) in Nepalgunj, inaugurated after nearly two decades of India-Nepal agreement, promotes trade, eases bureaucracy, and includes advanced technology for seamless imports and exports.

content: Chiranjivi Nepal, who advised President Ramchandra Paudel on economics, resigned after saying that putting Nepal's new map on the 100 rupee note was a bad idea. title:
**Politics and Education**

Politics can influence education by determining:

* Funding for schools and resources available to students.
* Curriculum and educational standards, shaping what students learn.
* School policies and regulations, impacting how students are treated.

Education, in turn, can influence politics by:

* Preparing citizens to participate in democratic processes.
* Fostering critical thinking and encouraging political engagement.
* Creating a more informed and engaged population that holds politicians accountable.
content:
Political engagement of teachers and students in Nepal has been a debated topic. Some argue that teachers should not be allowed to engage in politics while holding their educational positions.

During the Panchayat era, students played a role in spreading multiparty ideas. After the fall of the Panchayat, political parties saw students and teachers' unions as useful tools for promoting their ideas.

However, this has led to some negative consequences, with teachers and students working openly for political parties. Recently, the Education Minister proposed barring teachers from political activities.

The history of political engagement in educational institutions in Nepal is complex and dates back to the early days of the Panchayat system. It is important to look at the students' political inclinations in a historical order.

Students have a great history of fighting for freedom and academic accomplishments, and they should keep up that tradition. Teachers should stop becoming the cadres of political parties, and political parties should stop using students and teachers for their politics.

The situation requires a prudent and creative approach to balancing the political aspirations of students and teachers with the need to maintain educational institutions free from political activism.
summary: Political engagement of teachers and students in Nepal's educational institutions has become a hot debate, with proposals to bar teachers from political activities while acknowledging the historical influence of student political activism amidst party influence and hegemony.

This push is driven by geopolitical ambitions, economic interests, and religious and cultural connections. content:

**Pakistan**

* Pakistan is concerned about Iran's growing ties with India and the development of the Chabahar port.
* During his visit, Iranian President Raisi signed agreements to improve trade and economic ties between the two countries.

* Raisi inaugurated an Iranian-funded electricity and irrigation project in Sri Lanka.
* Sri Lanka and Iran have signed an agreement to trade tea for oil.

summary: Iranian President Raisi's visits to Pakistan and Sri Lanka strengthen ties amidst regional tensions, including Iran's retaliatory drone and missile strike on Israel, while both nations seek support amid economic challenges.

title:
**Reasons to Become a Teacher:**

* **Make a Difference:** Shape young minds and empower students to reach their potential.
* **Inspire and Educate:** Share knowledge, passion, and critical thinking skills.
* **Personal Growth:** Continuously learn and develop as you guide students.
* **Meaningful Work:** Experience the fulfillment of making a positive impact on society.
* **Job Security:** Benefit from stable employment and opportunities for professional advancement.
* **Community Involvement:** Connect with families and contribute to the well-being of your students' community.
* **Summer Breaks:** Enjoy extended time off during the summer months.
content:
**Teaching Is Valuable but Undervalued**

The saying "Those who can't, teach" is wrong. Teaching is a noble profession that requires courage and patience. Yet, teachers in Bangladesh are often underpaid and undervalued.

This creates a societal hierarchy where careers like entertainment and sports are seen as more prestigious. As a result, fewer people want to be teachers.

To fix this, we need to:

* Increase teacher pay
* Reduce corruption and unprofessionalism
* Define what makes a good teacher (not just knowledge)
* Value teachers as role models and torchbearers of values
summary: Low teacher pay and lack of recognition contribute to teaching's low status, but increasing salaries alone won't solve the problem, as other factors like corruption, lack of professionalism, and inadequate teacher evaluation need to be addressed alongside value-based education.

title: Wildfires are threatening Fort McMurray, a major oil town in Canada. Residents have been ordered to evacuate to protect themselves from the flames.

title: Myths often reflect real-life experiences and emotions. They provide a way to understand the human condition and make sense of the world around us. Whether it's the hero's journey or the battle between good and evil, myths give us insight into our own struggles, triumphs, and fears.
content:
**Mandala Theatre's "Bakhaamma" Explores Destiny and Culture**

"Bakhaamma" questions fate and the divine, using the Kirati Mundum oral tradition. The play follows Saya and Sikhum, whose love story echoes that of deities on Salpa-Sailung mountain. The community accepts their marriage, reflecting the connection between myth and everyday life.

The play highlights the Kirati belief in animalism and nature harmony. The goddess Sumnina has animal friends, showcasing the community's respect for the environment. The production features stunning sets, costumes, and music, immersing the audience in the story.

Actress Alisha Rai shines as both Saya and Sumnina. The play also explores themes of love, loneliness, and community. Despite some confusion in the storytelling, "Bakhaamma" celebrates Kirati culture and promotes Nepali theater.

Additional information:

* Director: Rajan Murarung
* Cast: Alisha Rai, Sachin Ratna, Anil Subba, Sangmi Sunuwar
* Language: Nepali
* Duration: 1 hour 45 minutes
* Showtimes: 5:30 pm (daily except Mondays), 1 pm (Saturdays)
* Venue: Mandala Theatre, Thapagaun, New Baneshwar, Kathmandu
* Runs until May 27
summary: 'Bakhaama' by Mandala Theatre explores the interplay of human destiny, divine love, and cultural identity through the tale of Saya and Sikhum's elopement, uncovering the Kirati Mundum's rich mythology, community bonds, and the significance of nature.

title: Brother serving in Russian army passed away. Younger brother cannot be reached.
content: A Nepali woman, Chandani Bista, was protesting for the safe return of her husband, Birajan, and other Nepalis serving in the Russian army. On May 3, she received news of Birajan's death and performed his final rites using a dummy. Birajan had been serving in the Russian army for five months before being killed. His family has not been able to contact his brother, Nirajan, who is also serving in the Russian army. The families of Nepali youths in the Russian army are demanding their safe return, compensation for the injured, and the repatriation of those killed. They also want details of all Nepalis serving in the Russian army and action taken against those who recruited them.
summary: Chandani Bista, whose husband Birajan was serving in the Russian army, received unverified news of his death; despite performing final rites, the family remains hopeful for his return, along with several other Nepali youths serving in Russia for whom protests and demands have been made.

title: Dr. Govinda KC is on his 22nd hunger strike to protest corruption in Nepal's medical system.
content:
**Dr. Govinda KC on Hunger Strike for 22nd Time**

Dr. Govinda KC has started his 22nd hunger strike because the government hasn't kept its promises to him. These promises include:

* Improving the justice system
* Fixing the healthcare and education systems
* Providing free healthcare for everyone

title: Congress will keep blocking Parliament until their demands are met.
content:
The main opposition party in Nepal, the Nepali Congress, is refusing to participate in Parliament until an investigation is launched into Home Minister Rabi Lamichhane over his alleged involvement in a cooperatives scam.

Despite the opposition party's flexibility and efforts to resolve the issue, the government and the Parliament Speaker have not addressed their demands.

The Nepali Congress will continue to block Parliament until their demands are met, and they are considering taking a tougher stance in the future.
summary: Nepali Congress continues to obstruct parliament, demanding a parliamentary investigation into Home Minister Lamichhane's alleged involvement in a cooperatives scam.

title: Nepal plans to use drones to remove garbage from Mount Everest to reduce pollution and maintain the mountain's beauty.
content:
**Drones to Collect Garbage on Mount Everest**

To reduce the risk faced by support staff, the local government is testing heavy-lift drones to collect garbage from Mount Everest. The drones can fly up to 6,500 meters and carry 30 kilograms.

**Potential Impact on Support Staff**

If the drone tests are successful, it could affect the livelihood of high-altitude support staff who currently carry heavy loads up the mountain. However, the drones could also prevent accidents caused by avalanches on the dangerous Khumbu Icefall.

**Garbage Management Rules**

To protect the environment, new rules have been implemented:

* Climbers must strap on a GPS device or tracking chip.
* Base camp sleeping areas are limited to 80 square feet per person.
* Poop bags are mandatory above base camp.
* Old ropes must be removed and brought back.

**Other Regulations**

* Alcohol sales are prohibited at base camp.
* Bright lights are not allowed at night.
* Recovering bodies from extreme points of the mountain is expensive and may not be possible.
summary: Drones are being tested on Everest to retrieve garbage, potentially impacting high-altitude support staff who navigate the dangerous Khumbu Icefall.

title: Adoption process in Nepal is difficult because there are no clear rules or laws. This makes it hard for people to understand the process and adopt children safely and legally.
content:
**Adoption in Nepal**

Anistha Shrestha wanted a baby for years but faced challenges. She and her husband decided to adopt.

In 2017, they found an abandoned baby boy and raised him as their own. Adoption was difficult then, but a law in 2017 made it easier.

To adopt in Nepal:
* File an application with the court
* Meet certain criteria (e.g., married for 10 years or over 45 years old)

Still, the adoption process is not always smooth due to:
* Lack of guidelines and committees
* Potential parents having to find children on their own
* Social stigma surrounding adoption

Queer couples face additional barriers because they are not legally recognized.

Intercountry adoption was popular in the past but has been banned since 2019 due to concerns about child trafficking and abuse.
summary: After struggling for a decade to have a child, Anistha Shrestha and her husband found an abandoned baby boy and raised him as their own, highlighting Nepal's cumbersome adoption process despite legal changes in 2017, which still face challenges in regulation, matching children with parents, and addressing child safety and abuse concerns.

title: Nepal is aiming to attract LGBTQI+ tourists, targeting a multi-billion dollar market.
content: Nepal hosted an international conference for LGBTIQ tourism. The conference aims to promote tourism among LGBTIQ people, who spend billions of dollars on travel each year. Nepal legalized same-sex marriage last year, and hopes to attract more LGBTIQ tourists by creating a safe and welcoming environment. The conference featured presentations on the economic benefits of LGBTIQ tourism, and the importance of inclusiveness in tourism. Nepal's Tourism Board is investing in creating a more friendly and enabled environment for LGBTIQ tourists, including training trekking guides and promoting businesses owned by members of the LGBTIQ community. Nepal's unique culture, including its recognition of six genders, offers a special experience for LGBTIQ tourists. The conference is expected to support Nepal's economy and help the LGBTIQ community gain jobs and recognition.
summary: Nepal hosted the first LGBTIQ tourism conference after legalizing same-sex marriage in 2023, aiming to attract the multi-billion dollar "pink market" and foster economic opportunities for the community.

title:
Middle East conflict is getting worse and could hurt Nepal's economy by:

* Causing high oil prices
* Reducing tourism
* Making it harder to send money back home
content:
**Nepal faces economic risks due to Middle East tensions:**

* **High dependence on remittances:** Many Nepalis work in the Middle East, sending money back home.
* **Possible job losses:** Tensions could lead to job losses and reduced earnings for Nepalese workers.
* **Increased inflation:** Conflict in oil-producing countries can raise oil prices, which Nepal heavily depends on.
* **Reduced foreign currency reserves:** Less remittances could reduce Nepal's foreign currency savings.
* **Supply chain disruptions:** Conflict could disrupt shipping, leading to higher costs for importing goods.
* **Negative impact on tourism:** Travel advisories due to tensions could discourage tourists from visiting Nepal.
* **Government needs to prepare for potential shocks:** Nepal's economy could suffer if labor markets in the Middle East are impacted.
summary: Escalating tensions in the Middle East may disrupt labor markets and impact remittance-dependent Nepal's economy, leading to decreased foreign currency reserves, inflation, and potential social unrest due to rising unemployment and reduced tourist arrivals.

content: Project Sambad was created by a group of Nepali institutions to encourage deep discussions about Nepali society and politics. The first event happened in Kathmandu in March. This interview discusses the state of public debates in Nepal and how to improve them.
summary: Project Sambad, co-convened by Neupane, hosted its inaugural event in Kathmandu to facilitate critical discussions on Nepali society and policy-making.

title: The Constitution of Nepal defines Nepal as a multi-ethnic, multilingual, democratic, secular, and an inclusive country. It is a federal republic with seven provinces and 753 local governments. The Nepalese people have the right to freedom of speech, religion, and assembly. The constitution also protects the rights of women, children, and minorities.
content: Bipin Adhikari is an expert on constitutional law in Nepal. He teaches at Kathmandu University. He talks about the key aspects of Nepal's 2015 constitution, how long it is likely to last, and how Nepal's constitution has changed over time.

title: In Nepal's Madhesh region, tensions are rising after the split in the JSP (Janata Samajbadi Party). Discord centers on the future of the provincial coalition, with competing claims from both factions of the JSP and the ruling Nepali Congress.
content:
**Madhesh Provincial Government Faces Crisis**

The split in the Janata Samajbadi Party (JSP) may lead to a change in leadership in the Madhesh provincial government.

* The CPN (Maoist Centre), which supports the current JSP-led government, is discussing forming a new one.
* The UML, the largest party in the provincial assembly, may also seek leadership.
* Political experts believe the incumbent JSP-led government may not last due to poor performance and resentment.
* The fate of the government depends on decisions made by the central coalition in Kathmandu.
summary: Janata Samajbadi Party-Nepal's split threatens the Madhesh provincial government, with the CPN (Maoist Centre) and UML potentially forming a new government led by the UML.

title: Yadav to challenge registration of new political party in court.
content: The Janata Samajbadi Party Nepal plans to challenge the Election Commission's recognition of a new party led by Ashok Rai, saying it's illegal. The leaders of the new party claim they had to leave due to autocratic leadership. The Election Commission registered the new party based on a regulation, as there are no laws for party splits. The original party says it will take legal action because the regulation is no longer valid. Despite rumors, the original party says it will continue to support the ruling alliance.
summary: Janata Samajbadi Party Nepal announces legal challenge against Election Commission's recognition of a splinter group as a separate political party.

title: Political parties change their positions and opinions to suit their own needs or advantage, rather than staying true to their core principles.
content:
**Summary:**

Last year, UML demanded an investigation into gold smuggling involving Congress and Maoists. Congress opposed it.

Now, Congress (in opposition) wants to investigate Home Minister Lamichhane for alleged cooperative embezzlement, but UML (in government) opposes it.

UML says their past demand for a judicial probe in gold smuggling is different from Congress's current demand for a parliamentary probe on Lamichhane.

Congress argues that the investigation needed because the government is protecting Lamichhane and wants a probe committee to ensure accountability.

Both UML and Congress have changed their stance on probe committees based on their position in government or opposition.

Political experts find it concerning that political parties prefer probe committees instead of trusting state institutions.
summary: Despite differing positions based on government or opposition status, UML has rejected Congress' demand for a parliamentary inquiry committee against Deputy Prime Minister Rabi Lamichhane, accused of embezzlement, citing the success of a previous judicial commission in the gold smuggling case.

title: Nepali Congress may allow Rabi Lamichhane, the Chief of Rastriya Swatantra Party, to speak in parliament.
content:
**Nepali Congress Demands Investigation into Home Minister Lamichhane's Co-op Fund Scam**

The Nepali Congress party wants a parliamentary investigation into allegations of embezzlement of co-op fund by Deputy Prime Minister and Home Minister Rabi Lamichhane. They believe he misused police and the Attorney General's Office to avoid being investigated.

The government has proposed forming a committee to look into problems of the co-op sector, but the Nepali Congress wants this committee to also focus on Lamichhane specifically.

The party is determined to block House proceedings until the government agrees to their demand. They believe that the ruling parties are ignoring the concerns of the opposition.
summary: Nepali Congress demands parliamentary investigation into Deputy Prime Minister Lamichhane's alleged embezzlement of cooperative funds, despite government resistance.

content: Nepal Police has busted a gang allegedly involved in swindling youths of Rs55 million promising to send them to the United States and Canada through illegal routes.Kathmandu Valley Crime Investigation Office made them public amidst a press conference in Kathmandu on Friday.The arrestees have been identified as Tashi Sherpa, 47, Dimbuti Sherpa, 42, and Nima Sherpa, 19, of Sindhupalchok, according to Senior Superintendent of Police Sanuram Bhattarai.According to him, they allegedly duped ten people of Rs55 million.Meanwhile, a total of 15 Nepalis have been held hostage in different countries including Kenya on their way to the US and it has come to light that the gang took around Rs75 million from them as well.

title: Seven wards of Kolkata Municipal Corporation (KMC) have started waste segregation, while four more will start soon.
content:
Kathmandu has started separating trash into two types:

* **Degradable:** Can break down naturally (e.g., food scraps, paper)
* **Non-degradable:** Doesn't break down naturally (e.g., plastic, metal)

title: Nepal's banking industry leads South Asia in female employment.
content:
**Devna's Experience in the Banking Sector**

* Faced uncomfortable questions about marriage and motherhood during an interview.
* Struggled to balance work and life after marriage due to family responsibilities.
* Experienced lack of support from colleagues and insufficient feedback.
* Promoted to middle management but still faced challenges, such as interruptions during meetings and disrespect from subordinates.

* Despite a strong legal framework, women are underrepresented in leadership roles (23% in senior management).
* Social norms and discrimination create barriers for women to advance.
* Men often struggle to accept authority from women in senior positions.
* Family responsibilities disproportionately impact women's careers.

* Banks have policies aimed at improving gender diversity and inclusion.

title: Businesses call for government to spend heavily on infrastructure projects to boost the economy.
content:
**Nepal's Budget Expectations**

Nepal's private sector wants the government to spend more money in the upcoming budget to boost the economy. They believe that more government investment will encourage businesses to invest as well.

Experts say Nepal's economy is not growing fast enough because of low investment. The budget is expected to focus on supporting startups, exports, and tourism.

The private sector also wants the government to make it easier for businesses to borrow money and invest in new projects.

Banks are facing challenges, and the government needs to find ways to support them. The budget may also include measures to increase foreign investment.

The government says that it will prioritize private sector confidence and address the economic slowdown. It aims for an economic growth rate of 7% or higher.
summary: Amidst economic slowdown, Nepal's private sector urges government to prioritize capital expenditure, boost investment, and address banking concerns in the upcoming budget.

title: Volunteers and staff from Barahi Jungle Lodge worked together to clean up the park. They picked up trash, removed invasive plants, and cleaned up waterways. Their efforts helped to protect the park's ecosystem and improve the visitor experience.
content: Barahi Jungle Lodge cleaned up trash near Chitwan National Park to protect the environment. They have removed three tractorloads of trash and are certified as eco-friendly by the 'Toft Tiger' program and for their Environmental Management Systems.

title: New tunnel provides water to dry farmlands in Madhesh, bringing hope for agriculture.
content:
**Sunkoshi Marin Project: Irrigation and Power for Central Tarai**

A 13.3 km tunnel has been completed in Sindhuli district. This tunnel will divert water from the Sunkoshi River to the Marin River, which connects to the Bagmati River.

The project, costing Rs. 87 billion, will provide water for irrigation to 122,000 hectares of farmland in five districts. It will also generate 31.07 MW of electricity.

The project is expected to boost agriculture and reduce the trade deficit. It will also alleviate water shortages in the Bagmati River, benefiting farmers in Rautahat and Sarlahi districts.
summary: Sunkoshi Marin project's diversion tunnel, crucial for irrigating drought-prone central Tarai, achieved breakthrough, paving the way for completion and economic opportunities through hydropower and increased agricultural production.

title: Japanese food event from May 10th
content: Izakaya Hokkaido, a Japanese restaurant in Nepal, is hosting a 3-day Japanese food event from May 10th at the Radisson Hotel Kathmandu. The event aims to share Japanese food culture, introduce new flavors, and provide information about the cuisine. It starts at 6:30 pm each day.
summary: An authentic Japanese restaurant in Nepal, Izakaya Hokkaido, is hosting a three-day public Japanese food event at the Radisson Hotel Kathmandu from May 10, aiming to enhance culinary understanding and share gastronomic experiences.

title: Government plans to check pregnant women for mental health issues.
content:
To reduce maternal deaths, Nepal's health ministry will screen pregnant women for mental health issues, a growing cause of these deaths. The pilot program will start at Paropakar Maternity Hospital in Kathmandu and expand to other districts later.

In the past, Nepal has reduced maternal deaths from 539 per 100,000 births in 1996 to 239 in 2016, but they have started to rise again. The latest report shows that 6% of maternal deaths were due to self-harm during pregnancy.

The ministry hopes that early screening and treatment will help prevent these deaths. The screening will cover all pregnant women seeking services at the hospital during both pregnancy and after giving birth.

The ministry has also made eight antenatal care visits and three postnatal care visits mandatory for women. Other programs include free institutional delivery service and travel allowances for those opting for institutional delivery and antenatal visits.

Nepal aims to reduce the maternal mortality rate to 75 per 100,000 births by 2030.
summary: Nepal's Health Ministry plans to screen pregnant women for mental health issues, a leading cause of maternal deaths, as part of efforts to reduce rising mortality rates.

title: Doctors and healthcare workers receive training to screen for non-communicable diseases (NCDs), such as diabetes, heart disease, and stroke. This training helps them identify and refer patients who need further care.
content:
**50 Health Workers Trained to Screen for Non-Communicable Diseases**

Health workers in Kathmandu are now trained to check for diseases like high blood pressure, diabetes, and mental health issues.

These trained workers will screen patients at local health facilities and give medicine, advice, or refer them to a hospital if needed.

Non-communicable diseases are now a major health problem, causing 71% of deaths in Nepal.

Even though the government gives free medicine for some non-communicable diseases, many people don't know they have them because they've never been screened.

The Health Ministry is hoping that free screening will help diagnose and treat non-communicable diseases earlier, saving lives.
summary: Kathmandu Health Office trained 50+ health workers to screen for non-communicable diseases (e.g., hypertension, heart disease, cancer) at local health facilities, where free medicines are available for some ailments.

title: Only 2% of new medicines on the market have been tested in children within 9 months of approval.
content:
**Summary of Medicine Quality in Nepal**

* Department tested 348 medicine samples out of 20,000 available in the market.
* Some samples collected 13 months ago haven't been tested yet, and may have expired.
* Some tested samples were found substandard and recalled from the market.
* Department admits it has tested too few samples to ensure overall quality.
* Department is understaffed and laboratory is slow, leading to delays in testing.
* Drug companies have the responsibility to ensure medicine quality, but testing all medicines is not possible.
* Random samples are collected and tested.
* If drugs are found substandard, companies are told to recall them.
* Delays in testing mean substandard drugs may already be sold when results come in.
summary: Despite collecting hundreds of drug samples for testing, the Department of Drug Administration has tested less than 2% of registered drugs, leaving patients vulnerable to substandard medicines due to delayed testing and inadequate sample collection.

title: Air pollution causing asthma in young children.
content:
**Air Pollution in Nepal**

**Problem:**
* Air pollution is getting worse in Nepal, especially in Kathmandu and Saptari.
* This is causing more children to have asthma, which can lead to lung damage if not treated.

**Causes:**
* Forest fires, cars, factories, and burning farm waste are making the air toxic.

**Health Effects:**
* Asthma, lung problems, skin diseases, and other health issues.
* Pregnancy loss, organ underdevelopment, and shorter life expectancy.

**Who's Most at Risk:**
* People living in areas with high air pollution, especially small children and women.

**What to Do:**
* Seek medical help if your child has shortness of breath or wheezing.
* Be aware of other triggers for asthma, such as allergies.
* Air pollution is shortening the lives of Nepalis by around 5 years.
summary: Air pollution, primarily from forest fires and vehicular emissions, has led to a surge in childhood asthma cases in Kathmandu, with polluted air significantly shortening life expectancy.

title: Residents in seven districts will receive medicine to prevent elephantiasis.
content:
**Lymphatic filariasis (elephantiasis) campaign underway in Nepal**

The government is giving anti-elephantiasis medicine to everyone over two years old in seven districts. This is the last year of the campaign, so it's important for everyone to take the medicine.

Lymphatic filariasis is a disease spread by mosquitoes that can cause swelling in the legs, arms, and genitals. It can lead to disability and social stigma.

The medicine is safe and effective. Health workers will visit every home to make sure everyone gets the medicine.

The government has been working to eliminate lymphatic filariasis in Nepal since 2003. The disease has been eliminated from 70 districts so far.

This year's campaign could be the last, so it's important to take the medicine now.
summary: Nepal's Epidemiology and Disease Control Division prepares for mass anti-elephantiasis drug administration in seven endemic districts, aiming to eliminate the disease by 2030.

title: taking-nepali-taste-to-new-york
content:
**Nepali Chef in New York Elevates Nepali Cuisine**

Aditya Mishra, a Nepali chef in New York City, is passionate about sharing Nepali food worldwide. He started his supper club, "The Sewing Tin," to offer fine dining with a sense of community and storytelling.

**Inspiration and Journey**

Mishra's interest in cooking began as a teenager, when he was drawn to cooking shows and the stories of famous chefs. He studied engineering but later left to pursue his passion.

**The Sewing Tin**

The concept of "The Sewing Tin" originated from Mishra's desire to create a more personal and communal dining experience for immigrants. The name reflects the immigrant experience of finding sewing supplies instead of food in cookie boxes.

**Celebrating Nepali Cuisine**

Mishra's menu at "The Sewing Tin" celebrates both his Nepali and his partner's Indian heritage. He uses authentic techniques and ingredients to present Nepali dishes like kachaila and chatamari to New York City diners.

**Future of Nepali Cuisine**

Mishra believes Nepali cuisine has the potential to wow taste buds everywhere. He is on a mission to share it globally and explore more of Nepal's diverse culinary traditions.

**Challenges and Advice**

Being an outsider in New York has its challenges, but Mishra advises embracing opportunities and staying true to one's culture. He encourages chefs to be creative and avoid copying popular trends.

**Signature Dish: Confit Duck Chatamari**

Mishra's signature dish combines a traditional Nepali delicacy with French influence. The dish features shredded duck on a chatamari pancake, topped with garlic aioli, pickled onions, and scallions.
summary: Nepali chef Aditya Mishra, inspired by his culinary journey in New York and desire to elevate Nepali cuisine globally, established The Sewing Tin restaurant, blending Nepali traditions with modern culinary techniques to promote Nepali food and storytelling, while facing challenges as an outsider.

title:

title: Potatoes are an important food source worldwide, providing carbohydrates, vitamin C, and minerals. They come in different varieties with varying colors, shapes, and textures. Potatoes are versatile and can be prepared in many ways, such as boiling, baking, frying, and mashing. They are a good source of energy and can be part of a healthy diet when consumed in moderation.
content:
**Potatoes: A Vital Food in Nepal**

Potatoes are a widely eaten and nutritious food in Nepal. They are:

* **Cheap and versatile:** Used in most dishes and curries.
* **Nutrient-rich:** Contain vitamins, minerals, and fiber, which benefit the body's health.
* **Energy-rich:** Provide carbohydrates and other nutrients.

**Potato Production and Import**

Nepal produces a lot of potatoes, but also imports some. Different types of potatoes are available, including red, white, and dark potatoes.

**Benefits of Potatoes**

Potatoes have many health benefits:

* Support heart and muscle health with potassium.
* Aid digestion with fiber.
* Provide energy with carbohydrates.
* Contain antioxidants that protect cells.

**Cooking Potatoes**

How potatoes are cooked affects their nutritional value. Frying can reduce nutrients.

**Caution for People with Diabetes**

Potatoes can raise blood sugar, so people with diabetes should limit their intake.
summary: Potatoes, a widely consumed crop in Nepal, provide essential nutrients like vitamins, minerals, and fiber, benefitting health, though excessive intake of junk potato products should be avoided, especially for diabetics.

title:

* **Good source of healthy fats:** Supports brain and cell function.
* **Excellent source of vitamins:** A, D, E, and B12.

content:

* Help with weight loss, lower blood pressure, and fight infections

summary: Chicken eggs, a nutritious superfood containing essential minerals and vitamins, offer numerous health benefits including weight loss, reduced blood pressure, and protection against infections, contributing to reduced malnutrition in Nepal.

content:

title: Architecture meets art, creating spaces that are both functional and aesthetically pleasing.
content:
**Lucknow's Bara Imambara: A Timeless Marvel**

Lucknow's Bara Imambara welcomes visitors with a smile. This historic building, constructed in 1784, offers a glimpse into Lucknow's rich past.

The complex features:

* **Rumi Darwaza:** A grand entrance gate.
* **Asafi Mosque:** An elegant white mosque with intricate carvings.
* **Asafi Hall:** A vast, pillar-less hall with a secret support system.
* **Bhool Bhulaiyaa (Labyrinth):** A confusing network of corridors and staircases.
* **Shahi Baoli (Stepwell):** An underground well with a well-thought-out design.

The Bara Imambara is a testament to the architectural ingenuity of the past. Its beauty, mystery, and historical significance make it an unforgettable destination.
summary: Bara Imambara, a grand 18th-century palace in Lucknow, boasts an impressive Asafi Mosque, a gravity-defying Asafi Hall, a labyrinthine Bhool Bhulaiyaa, a rooftop view of the city, and an underground Shahi Baoli with intricate Mughal carvings and a unique security system.

title: Explore the best hiking trails and treks for various skill levels. Discover hidden gems, scenic landscapes, and challenging adventures on foot.

* Guides are essential for safety and support.

* **Maintain a positive mindset:** Believe you can do it.
* **Prepare physically:** Start training 1 month before the trek.
* **Pack wisely:** Choose lightweight, warm clothing and essential items.
* **Manage periods:** Pack necessary supplies and communicate with others about discomfort.
* **Communicate effectively:** Build relationships with fellow trekkers and guides.

**Challenges for Female Trekkers**

* Female trekkers may face underestimation and demeaning comments.
* They can overcome this by proving their abilities and supporting each other.

**Becoming a Trekking Guide**

* Join a trekking association and enroll in a guide course.
* Colleges offer mountaineering programs for aspiring guides.
summary: Mountain climbing in Nepal requires preparation, a positive mindset, and essential gear, with guides essential for support, especially for female trekkers facing challenges.

title:
**Solo Travel in Nepal**

Traveling in Nepal as a solo traveler is a rewarding experience. Here's a summary:

* **Safety:** Nepal is generally safe for solo travelers, but take usual precautions.
* **Accommodation:** Wide range of options available, from budget guesthouses to luxury resorts.
* **Transportation:** Public transportation is affordable and reliable, but taxis and private tours are also available.
* **Activities:** Trek to the Himalayas, visit ancient temples, or explore vibrant cities.

content:

**Good solo travel destinations in Nepal:**

title: Israel has told more people in the Rafah area of Gaza to leave their homes.
content: Israel called on Saturday for Palestinians in more areas of Gaza’s southern city of Rafah to evacuate and head to what it calls an expanded humanitarian area in Al-Mawasi, in a further indication that the military is pressing ahead with its plans for a ground attack on Rafah.In a post on social media site X, a military spokesperson also called on residents and displaced people in the Jabalia area of northern Gaza, and 11 other neighbourhoods in the enclave to go immediately to the shelters west of Gaza City.According to the Palestinian news agency WAFA, 24 Palestinians were killed overnight after Israeli jets targeted several areas in central Gaza.Despite heavy US pressure and alarm expressed by residents and humanitarian groups, Israel has said it will proceed with an incursion into Rafah, where more than 1 million displaced people have sought refuge during the seven-month-old war.Israel’s military said that so far, about 300,000 Gazans have moved towards Al-Mawasi.Israel says it cannot win the war without rooting out thousands of fighters of the Islamist Hamas movement it believes are deployed in Rafah.Israeli tanks captured the main road dividing Rafah’s eastern and western sections on Friday, effectively encircling the eastern side in an assault that has caused Washington to hold up delivery of some military aid to its ally.The White House said on Friday it was watching the Israeli operations “with concern,” but they appeared to be localized around the shuttered Rafah crossing and did not reflect a large-scale invasion of the city.The war was triggered by a Hamas-led attack on southern Israel in which some 1,200 people were killed and more than 250 people taken hostage, according to Israeli tallies.Israel's military operation in Gaza, which it says aims to eliminate Hamas, has killed close to 35,000 Palestinians, according to Gaza's health ministry. The bombardment has laid waste to the coastal enclave and caused a deep humanitarian crisis.The Biden administration said on Friday Israel’s use of US-supplied weapons may have violated international humanitarian law during its Gaza operation, in its strongest criticism to date of Israel.But the administration stopped short of a definitive assessment, saying that due to the chaos of the war it could not verify specific instances where use of those weapons might have been involved in alleged breaches.
summary: Amidst ongoing Israeli military operations, residents of Rafah, Jabalia, and other Gaza areas have been urged to evacuate to designated areas, with 24 Palestinians killed in overnight airstrikes and Israel considering a ground attack on Rafah.
